ARGUMENT
I. THE DISTRICT COURT PROPERLY UPHELD THE CIAโS GLOMAR
RESPONSE, CORRECTLY REJECTING PLAINTIFFSโ CONTENTION
THAT  THE  EXISTENCE  OR  NONEXISTENCE  OF  RESPONSIVE
RECORDS HAD BEEN OFFICIALLY DISCLOSED.
A. A Glomar Response Is Appropriate When An Agency Can Neither
Confirm Nor Deny The Existence Of Requested Records Without
Revealing Information That Is Exempt From Disclosure Under
FOIA.
The FOIA generally mandates disclosure of Government records unless the
requested information falls within an enumerated exemption.  See 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(b). 
Notwithstanding  the  FOIAโs  โliberal  congressional  purpose,โ  the  statutory
exemptions must be given โmeaningful reach and application.โ  John Doe Agency v.
John Doe Corp., 493 U.S. 146, 152 (1989).  โRequiring an agency to disclose exempt
information is not authorized[.]โ  Minier v. CIA, 88 F.3d 796, 803 (9th Cir. 1996).
Agency decisions to withhold information under the FOIA are reviewed de
novo, and the agency bears the burden of proving that the withheld information falls
within the exemption it invokes.  5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(B); King v. Department of
Justice, 830 F.2d 210, 217 (D.C. Cir. 1987).  Generally, an agency may meet its
burden under FOIA by submitting a declaration that โdescribe[s] the justifications for
nondisclosure  with  reasonably  specific  detail  [and]  demonstrate[s]  that  the
information withheld logically falls within the claimed exemptions.โ  Hunt v. CIA,
18

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 29 of 59
981 F.2d 1116, 1119 (9th Cir. 1992).  A court may grant summary judgment to the
Government entirely on the basis of information set forth in such an affidavit, so long
as the affidavit is โโ not controverted by either contrary evidence in the record nor by
evidence of agency bad faith.โโ  Larson, 565 F.3d at 862 (quoting Miller v. Casey,
730 F.2d 773, 776 (D.C. Cir. 1984)).  โโUltimately, an agencyโs justification for
invoking a FOIA exemption is sufficient if it appears โlogicalโ or โplausible.โโ  Id.
(quoting Wolf v. CIA, 473 F.3d 370, 374-75 (D.C. Cir. 2007)).
The same standard applies when the Government issues a Glomar response,
refusing  to  acknowledge  whether  or  not  responsive  records  exist:  in  such
circumstances, the agencyโs affidavit must explain how the fact of the existence or
non-existence of responsive records constitutes information protected by a FOIA
exemption.  Phillippi v. CIA, 546 F.2d 1009, 1013 (D.C. Cir. 1976); Electronic
Privacy Information Center, 2012 WL 1654943 at *2; Wolf, 473 F.3d at 374 (โIn
determining whether the existence of agency records vel non fits a FOIA exemption,
courts apply the  general exception review standard established in non-Glomar
cases.โ).
A Glomar response is appropriate where, as here, confirming or denying
whether responsive records exist would itself cause the harm that a given FOIA
exemption is intended to prevent.  See, e.g., Electronic Privacy Information Center,
19

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 30 of 59
2012 WL 1654943 at *2; Wilner v. NSA, 592 F.3d 60, 68 (2d Cir. 2009) (โThe
Glomar doctrine is well settled as a proper response to a FOIA request because it is
the  only way in which an agency may assert  that a  particular FOIA  statutory
exemption covers the โexistence or nonexistence of the requested recordsโ in a case
in which a plaintiff seeks such records.โ), cert. denied, 131 S. Ct. 387 (2010);
Bassiouni v. CIA, 392 F.3d 244, 246 (7th Cir. 2004) (โEvery appellate court to
address the issue has held that the FOIA permits the [agency] to make a โGlomar
responseโ when it fears that inferences * * * or selective disclosure could reveal
classified sources or methods of obtaining foreign intelligence.โ); Minier, 88 F.3d at
800 (โ[A] government agency may issue a โGlomar Response,โ that is, refuse to
confirm or deny the existence of certain records, if the FOIA exemption would itself
preclude the acknowledgment of such documents.โ); Gardels v. CIA, 689 F.2d 1100,
1103 (D.C. Cir. 1982) (โ[A]n agency may refuse to confirm or deny the existence of
records where to answer the FOIA inquiry would cause harm cognizable under an
FOIA exception.โ).
โIn reviewing an agencyโs Glomar response, this Court exercises caution when
the  information  requested  โimplicat[es]  national  security,  a  uniquely  executive
purview.โโ  Electronic Privacy Information Center, 2012 WL 1654943 at *2 (quoting
Center for National Security Studies v. Department of Justice, 331 F.3d 918, 926-27
20

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 31 of 59
(D.C. Cir. 2003)).  Indeed, the Supreme Court has cautioned that โweigh[ing] the
variety  of  complex  and  subtle  factors  in  determining  whether  disclosure  of
information may lead to an unacceptable risk of compromisingโ national security is
a task best left to the Executive Branch.  CIA v. Sims, 471 U.S. 159, 180 (1985); see
also Center for National Security Studies, 331 F.3d at 928 (โ[T]he judiciary is in an
extremely poor position to second-guess the executiveโs judgment in [the] area of
national security.โ); Halperin v. CIA, 629 F.2d 144, 148 (D.C. Cir. 1980) (โJudges
* * * lack the expertise necessary to second-guess * * * agency opinions in the typical
national security FOIA case.โ).
As  a  result,  in  the  FOIA  context,  courts  have  โconsistently  deferred  to
executive affidavits predicting harm to the national security, and have found it unwise
to undertake searching judicial review.โ  Center for National Security Studies, 331
F.3d at 927; see also Wilner, 592 F.3d at 69 (โThe โ[a]ffidavits submitted by an
agency are accorded a presumption of good faith.โ); Students Against Genocide v.
Department of State, 257 F.3d 828, 840 (D.C. Cir. 2001) (โ[S]ubstantial weight [is]
owed to agency explanations in the context of national security, to qualify for
withholding under Exemptions 1 and 3.โ); Salisbury v. United States, 690 F.2d 966,
970 (D.C. Cir. 1982) (noting that agencies possess โunique insightsโ into the adverse
effects that might result from public disclosure of classified information); Gardels,
21

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 32 of 59
689 F.2d at 1104-05 (โOnce satisfied that proper procedures have been followed and
that the information logically falls into the exemption claimed, the courts โneed not
go further to test the expertise of the agency, or to question its veracity when nothing
appears to raise the issue of good faith.โโ).
The existence of media reports based on unsourced comments and other
unofficial statements that relate to the information that a FOIA requester seeks from
the Government does not diminish the importance of a Glomar response by an
agency, particularly in the area of national security and foreign affairs.  That is
because, โ[a]s a practical matter, foreign governments can often ignore unofficial
disclosures of CIA activities that might be viewed as embarrassing or harmful to their
interests.โ  See Wilson v. CIA, 586 F.3d 171, 186 (2d Cir. 2009).  Official government
acknowledgment of whether media or other unofficial claims are accurate or not, is
a different matter.  See Afshar v. Department of State, 702 F.2d 1125, 1130-31 (D.C.
Cir. 1983) (โofficial acknowledgment by an authoritative source might well be new
information that could cause damage to the national securityโ); ACLU, 628 F.3d at
625 (recognizing โthat even if information exists in some form in the public domain
that does not mean that official disclosure will not cause harm cognizable under a
FOIA exemptionโ).

C. The  Agency  Has  Not  Officially  Disclosed  The  Existence  Or
Nonexistence Of Records That Would Be Responsive To Plaintiffsโ
FOIA Request.
The sole issue plaintiffs raise on appeal is whether, assuming that the district
court correctly decided that FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3 could justify the CIAโs
Glomar response, the CIA is nonetheless precluded from invoking the Glomar
23

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 34 of 59
response because the Agency has officially acknowledged the existence of CIA
records concerning the lethal use of drones.  Although plaintiffsโ FOIA request
sought several discrete categories of records concerning the lethal use of drones โby
the CIA and the Armed Forces,โ JA 48, on appeal plaintiffs appear to narrow the
scope of their request to โthe CIAโs useโ of lethal drones.  Br. at 2.  In any event,
regardless of whether plaintiffs maintain their broader request or now focus only on
a narrow characterization, their contention that the CIA cannot use a Glomar response
because it has officially acknowledged an involvement or intelligence interest in
drone strikes (and records related thereto) is without merit.  Plaintiffs misconstrue
both the nature and scope of the โofficial acknowledgmentโ doctrine, as well as
various statements that they contend constitute official disclosures.
โ[W]hen information has been โofficially acknowledged,โ its disclosure may
be compelled even over an agencyโs otherwise valid exemption claim.โ  Fitzgibbon
v. CIA, 911 F.2d 755, 765 (D.C. Cir. 1990).  This Court, however, has recognized that
โโ[a] strict test applies to claims of official disclosure.โโ  Moore v. CIA, 666 F.3d at
1333 (quoting Wilson v. CIA, 586 F.3d 171, 186 (2d Cir. 2009)).  To constitute an
official  disclosure,  โ(1)  the  information  requested  must  be  as  specific  as  the
information  previously released; (2)  the  information  requested must match the
information previously disclosed; and (3) the information requested must already
24

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 35 of 59
have been made public through an official and documented disclosure.โ  ACLU v.
U.S. Department of Defense, 628 F.3d 612, 620-21 (D.C. Cir. 2011).
As a result, โ[a] plaintiff asserting a claim of prior disclosure bears the burden
of pointing to โspecific information in the public domain that appears to duplicate that
being withheld.โโ  Electronic Privacy Information Center, 2012 WL 1654943 at *4
(quoting Wolf, 473 F.3d at 378); Moore, 666 F.3d at 1333 (โin order to overcome an
agencyโs Glomar response based on an official acknowledgment, the requesting
plaintiff must pinpoint an agency record that both matches the plaintiffโs request and
has been publicly and officially acknowledged by the agencyโ); Wilner, 592 F.3d at
70 (agency is only โprecluded from making a Glomar response if the existence or
nonexistence of the specific records sought by the FOIA request has been the subject
of an official public acknowledgmentโ) (emphasis added).  Plaintiffs have failed to
satisfy this exacting standard to foreclose the CIAโs Glomar response.
Moreover, an agency may be found to have waived its ability to issue a Glomar
response only if a disclosure is โofficial and documented.โ  See ACLU, 628 F.3d at
620-21.  A statement by an unnamed agency official cannot constitute an official
disclosure.  See Wilson, 586 F.3d at 186 (โstatements made by a person not authorized
to speak for the Agencyโ do not constitute an official disclosure).  Also, a former
official of an agency is not authorized to make an official disclosure on the agencyโs
25

behalf.  See Afshar, 702 F.2d at 1134; cf. Frugone v. CIA, 169 F.3d 772, 774 (D.C.
Cir. 1999) (noting that public disclosure by OPM does not foreclose another federal
agency, the CIA, from issuing a Glomar response).  And speculation by journalists
or members of the public cannot constitute official disclosure, โno matter how
widespread.โ  Wolf, 473 F.3d at 378; see also Electronic Privacy Information Center,
2012 WL 1654943 at *4 (โnational media are not capable of waiving [an agencyโs]
statutory authority to protect informationโ).
Yet plaintiffsโ official disclosure argument here rests heavily on just these types
of statements.  See, e.g., Br. at 30-39.  Plaintiffs acknowledge (Br. at 36), as they
must, that these statements may not be used to support a claim of official disclosure.

acknowledging  the  interviewerโs  statement,  while  Panetta  was  waiting  for  the
interviewer to pose a question.  See 60 Minutes, The Killing of Anwar al-Awlaki (CBS
Jan.29, 2012), available at http://bit.ly/wEx57M.  But even assuming plaintiffs
correctly interpreted Panettaโs nod as a signal of agreement, that does not address
whether al-Awlaki was killed in a drone strike, let alone whether the CIA was
32

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 43 of 59
involved in any such strike.  As noted, Panetta was serving as Secretary of Defense,
not as CIA Director, both at the time of al-Awlakiโs death and at the time of the
interview.  Although the media has reported that al-Awlaki was killed in a drone
strike, see, e.g., Br. at 32-35 & n. 20, 22 (citing news articles), Panettaโs gesture in
no way constitutes an official acknowledgment that the CIA possesses responsive
records regarding drone strikes.
Plaintiffs further rely on Panettaโs statement in that same interview in which
he referred to a โrecommendation [to the President] that the CIA Director makes in
my prior role * * * .โ  See Br. at 20-21.  Contrary to plaintiffsโ contention, that
statement plainly says nothing about drone strikes.
Plaintiffs quote a statement by former Director Panetta, after he became
Secretary of Defense, in which he stated:  โโI have a hell of a lot more weapons
available to me in this job than I had at the CIA, although the Predators arenโt bad.โโ
Br. at 19.  The same article quoted him as saying that he โโwas very familiar with [the
use of Predators] in my past job.โโ  Br. at 20.  Contrary to plaintiffsโ suggestion,
however, those vague statements do not constitute official confirmation of CIA
records relating to drone strikes.  As for his aside of โalthough Predators arenโt bad,โ
this statement is too ambiguous to constitute an official disclosure that the CIA
possesses responsive records concerning drone strikes.  And even if this comment
33

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 44 of 59
could be read as acknowledging that Predators were โavailableโ to the CIA, it does
not acknowledge that the Agency uses them for lethal purposes, as opposed to
surveillance and intelligence-gathering.  Indeed, even the article acknowledged that
โPanetta stopped short of confirming that CIA Predators were conducting airstrikes.โ 
U.S.:  Defense  Secretary  Refers to CIA  Drone  Use, L.A. Times, Oct.  7,  2011,
available at http://lat.ms/roREDq.
In sum, former Director Panettaโs statements did not officially acknowledge
whether or not the CIA possesses responsive records relating to drone strikes.
2. The Presidentโs Statements Do Not Officially Acknowledge That
The CIA Conducts Drone Strikes Or Possesses Records Concerning
Drone Strikes.
Plaintiffs also refer to several statements made by President Obama that post-
date the district courtโs decision.  Br. at 24-26.  As with statements made by Panetta,
however, these statements do not officially acknowledge that the CIA possesses
responsive records regarding drone strikes.
Plaintiffs  first  rely  upon  a  video  forum,  during  which  the  President
โacknowledged that the United States carries out targeted killings using drones in
Pakistan.โ  Br. at 24 (emphasis added).  That statement does not disclose whether or
not the CIA carries out drone strikes or maintains responsive records regarding drone
strikes.  The remarks did not even mention the CIA.  See President Obama Hangs
34

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 45 of 59
Out  With  America,  White  House  Blog  (Jan.  30,  2012),
http://www.whitehouse.gov/blog/2012/01/30/president-obama-hangs-out-america.
Plaintiffs speculate that the President must have been speaking about CIA
involvement in drone strikes.  They base this inference upon the Presidentโs reference
to drone strikes in the Federally Administered Tribal Areas of Pakistan, and cite
media reports stating that the Department of Defense does not conduct drone strikes
in Pakistan.  Br. at 25 & n. 15.  It is precisely this sort of unbridled speculation that
is insufficient to support a claim of official disclosure.  See Wilson, 586 F.3d at 186
(โthe law will not infer official disclosureโ); Wolf, 473 F.3d at 378 (insisting โon
exactitudeโ before finding an official disclosure).
Indeed, plaintiffsโ argument piles inference upon inference.  They base their
contention that the Department of Defense does not conduct drone strikes in Pakistan
not upon any official sources, but upon unsourced statements in two media reports. 
See Br. at 25 n.15; โUS Droneโ Hits Pakistan Funeral, Al Jazeera, June 24, 2009,
http://aje.me/yKZJWO (quoting an unnamed Department of Defense official as
stating  that  โโ[t]here  are  no  US  military  strike  operations  being  conducted  in
Pakistanโโ); Karen DeYoung, U.S. Launches Airstrike Against al-Qaeda Affiliate in
Yemen, Wash. Post, Jan. 31, 2012, http://wapo.st/zSgzxq (stating, without reference
to any source, that โthe CIA has had sole responsibility for hundreds of drone strikes
35

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 46 of 59
[in Pakistan]โ).  But neither the statement of an unnamed agency official nor the
unattributed statement of a newspaper reporter can constitute official disclosure.  See
Wilson, 586 F.3d at 186 (โstatements made by a person not authorized to speak for
the Agencyโ do not constitute an official disclosure); ACLU, 628 F.3d at 621-22 (โโit
is one thing for a reporter or author to speculate or guess that a thing may be so or
even, quoting undisclosed sources, to say that it is so; it is quite another thing for one
in a position to know of it officially to say that it is so.โ); Afshar, 702 F.2d at 1130
(โeven if a fact * * * is the subject of widespread media and public speculationโ it
does not constitute official acknowledgment).
Moreover, even if plaintiffs could demonstrate  an official disclosure regarding
Department of Defense activities in Pakistan, which they cannot, it would require an
additional degree of speculation to infer that the President must have intended to
disclose that the CIA, as opposed to some other agency or entity of the United States,
is involved in drone strikes.  Accordingly, plaintiffsโ interpretation of President
Obamaโs statement as acknowledging the CIAโs role in drone strikes in Pakistan is
based on a series of unofficial speculations and is not an official disclosure of CIA
involvement as plaintiffs claim, let alone an acknowledgment as to the existence of
any CIA records about the same.
36

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 47 of 59
Plaintiffs also attempt to find official disclosure in two statements by the
President referring generally to al-Awlakiโs death.  But plaintiffsโ characterization of
those statements as acknowledging โparticular CIA drone strikesโ (Br. at 26) is
misleading.  The Presidentโs statements make no reference to either the CIA or to
drone strikes.  They discuss al-Awlakiโs death as a โsignificant milestone in the
broadr  effort  to  defeat  al  Qaeda  and  its  affiliates,โ  and  laud  the  โintelligence
communityโ for its efforts in that regard.  It is plaintiffs โ not the President โ who
inject references to supposed CIA drone strikes, based upon only media reports.
Moreover, President Obamaโs general statement that al-Awlakiโs death was โโa
tribute to our intelligence community,โโ Br. at 26, is unavailing.  This statement does
not explicitly identify the CIA, nor does it mention drone strikes.  The Presidentโs
comments regarding the โintelligence communityโ (which is made up of seventeen
federal organizations, not just the CIA) may well have been intended to praise the
community  for  its  role  in  collecting  and  analyzing  intelligence  that  may  have
contributed to this effort.  The Presidentโs statements do not constitute official
disclosure of whether or not the CIA possesses responsive records concerning drone
strikes.
Finally, plaintiffs argue that even if none of these statements (or those of
Director  Panetta)  by  themselves  constitutes  official  acknowledgment  of  CIA
37

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 48 of 59
responsive records concerning drone strikes, they should be considered collectively. 
See Br. at 26-29.  Plaintiffs suggest that the number of consistent statements counsels
in favor of finding that there has been an official acknowledgment.  Br. at 27.  But the
volume of disclosures, from whatever source, is not the test for official disclosure,
and plaintiffs fail to cite any โofficial acknowledgmentโ FOIA cases in support of that
proposition.  Cf. Wilson, 586 F.3d at 186 (requiring official disclosure to be by
authorized official); Wolf, 473 F.3d at 378 (speculation, โno matter how widespread,โ
cannot  constitute  official  disclosure).    More  significantly,  however,  even  if
considered collectively, those statements do not explicitly acknowledge that the CIA
has responsive records regarding drone strikes.
3. Statements By Former CIA Officials Or Unidentified Government
Officials Cannot Waive the Agencyโs Ability To Refuse To Confirm
Or Deny The Existence Of Responsive Records.
Plaintiffs also cite media reports containing statements by former CIA officials
and unidentified government officials.  Although plaintiffs concede that none of these
statements  alone  constitutes  an  official  acknowledgment,  Br.  at  30,  36,  they
nevertheless contend that, collectively, these statements โmake the CIAโs Glomar
invocation in this case particularly suspect, and particularly unseemly, and that they
warrant particularly searching review by this Court.โ  Br. at 30.  Plaintiffs, however,
38

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 49 of 59
fail to meet their burden of showing that such statements officially acknowledge the
existence of any CIA records regarding drone strikes.
Plaintiffs cite remarks made in 2011 by the CIAโs former Acting General
Counsel, John Rizzo, see Br. at 30, but plaintiffs readily acknowledge that โMr. Rizzo
was not in the employ of the CIA when he made these comments, and * * * plaintiffs
do not suggest that his comments, taken alone, establish official acknowledgement
[sic].โ  Br. at 30.  Indeed, the district court recognized in rejecting plaintiffsโ reliance
on Mr. Rizzoโs statements, that such statements by a former official cannot constitute
official acknowledgment.  See JA at 293 n. 6; see also Afshar, 702 F.2d at 1134
(holding that disclosures in books written by former CIA officials could not be treated
as โofficial disclosuresโ); Wilson v. CIA, 586 F.3d 171, 189 (2d Cir. 2009) (โA former
employeeโs public disclosure of classified information cannot be deemed an โofficialโ
act of the [Central Intelligence] Agency.โ); Phillippi v. CIA, 655 F.2d 1325, 1330-31
(D.C. Cir. 1981) (information reported in book by former CIA Director was not
official disclosure).  For that reason, plaintiffsโ reliance (Br. at 31) on comments by
former Director of National Intelligence Dennis Blair is also misplaced.
Plaintiffs contend that the White Houseโs counterterrorism advisor, John
Brennan, has disclosed the CIAโs involvement in drone strikes, citing an article in the
Los Angeles Times.  See Br. at 31 & n.18.  But that article made clear that Mr.
39

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 50 of 59
Brennan said no words to that effect; to the contrary, the author made clear that he
was inferring such meaning: โโBrennan presumably was referring to covert strikes by
the CIA and the Joint Special Operations Command[.]โโ  Br. at 31 (emphasis added). 
Nor did Mr. Brennanโs recent remarks on the Presidentโs counterterrorism strategy
acknowledge one way or the other the existence of any CIA intelligence interest in,
or involvement in, drone strikes.  See The Ethics and Efficacy of the Presidentโs
Counterterrorism Strategy, Transcript of Remarks by John O. Brennan (April 30,
2012), available at http://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/the-efficacy-and-ethics-us-
counterterrorism-strategy.  Although Mr. Brennan officially acknowledged that the
United States conducts drone strikes, id. (โthe United States Government conducts
targeted strikes against specific al-Qaโida terrorists, sometimes using remotely piloted
aircraft, often referred to publicly as dronesโ), he did not reveal whether the CIA (as
opposed to another federal entity such as the Department of Defense) is involved in
these drone strikes, or any other specific details.  Id.
Plaintiffs also cite a number of media reports, quoting various unnamed and/or
former government officials, that allegedly discuss the CIAโs involvement in drone
strikes.  See Br. at 31-36.  Plaintiffs argue that the โsheer volume of these statements
* * * suggests an official policy on the part of the agency and, more to the point,
underlines that the existence of the CIAโs drone strike program has been disclosed.โ 
40

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 51 of 59
Br. at 36-37 (emphasis added).  That argument, however, has been repeatedly rejected
by the courts.  As this Court has recognized, โ[a]n agencyโs official acknowledgment
* * * cannot be based on mere public speculation, no matter how widespread.โ  Wolf,
473 F.3d at 378 (emphasis added); see also Electronic Privacy Information Center,
2012 WL 1654943 at *4 n.5 (โnational media are not capable of waiving [an
agencyโs] statutory authority to protect informationโ); ACLU, 628 F.3d at 621-22 (โIt
is one thing for a reporter or author to speculate or guess that a thing may be so or
even, quoting undisclosed sources, to say that it is so; it is quite another thing for one
in a position to know of it officially to say that it is soโ); Fitzgibbon, 911 F.2d at 765
(recognizing โa critical difference between official and unofficial disclosuresโ);
Hudson River Sloop Clearwater, Inc. v. Department of Navy, 891 F.2d 414, 421 (2d
Cir. 1989) (statements made by a person without authority to speak for the agency
cannot constitute official disclosure).
These binding precedents are based upon the principle that, even if there is
speculation about a fact, unless an agency officially confirms that fact, the public
does not know whether it is so.  See Wilson, 586 F.3d at 186 (โAs a practical matter,
foreign governments can often ignore unofficial disclosures of CIA activities that
might be viewed as embarrassing or harmful to their interests.โ); Afshar, 702 F.2d at
1130-31 (โofficial acknowledgment by an authoritative source might well be new
41

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 52 of 59
information that could cause damage to the national securityโ); ACLU, 628 F.3d at
625 (recognizing โthat even if information exists in some form in the public domain
that does not mean that official disclosure will not cause harm cognizable under a
FOIA exemptionโ).  Indeed, if the law were to the contrary, agencies would be
required to confirm sensitive and/or classified information in a FOIA case whenever
an inadvertent disclosure or unauthorized leak of the requested information had
previously occurred.  Cf. Frugone, 169 F.3d at 775 (if another agencyโs disclosure
could constitute official acknowledgment on behalf of the CIA, then โthose with no
duties related to national security - could obligate agencies with responsibility in that
sphere to reveal classified informationโ).  Agencies would likewise be forced to issue
official denials in FOIA cases whenever the plaintiffs cited false reports from
unofficial sources about purportedly classified operations.
Even  in  cases  where  there  arguably  has  been  some  limited  official
acknowledgment of the information relating to the subject-matter at issue, courts have
nevertheless upheld the Governmentโs use of the Glomar response.  As the Second
Circuit explained in Wilner, โan agency may invoke the Glomar doctrine in response
to a FOIA request regarding a publicly revealed matter.  An agency only loses its
ability to provide a Glomar response when the existence or nonexistence of the
particular records covered by the Glomar response has been officially and publicly
42

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 53 of 59
disclosed.โ  592 F.3d at 70; accord Electronic Privacy Information Center, 2012 WL
1654943 at *4 (rejecting plaintiffโs argument that same information requested under
FOIA had been published on agencyโs website); Wolf, 473 F.3d at 379 (holding that
plaintiffs were entitled to disclosure only of the specific records whose existence had
been previously disclosed, but not to any others concerning the same subject). 
Plaintiffs nowhere assert that the CIA has officially disclosed the existence of
particular records that fall within their FOIA request.
Finally, plaintiffs argue that because โthe use of drones is not a secret method
of killing,โ Br. at 37, โthe CIAโs claim that the Glomar invocation serves a legitimate
purposeโ is undermined, Br. at 39.  Plaintiffsโ argument is wide of the mark. 
Notwithstanding widespread reports that drone strikes occur, the CIA has never
confirmed or denied whether it has any involvement or intelligence interest in any of
those drone strikes, or whether it maintains any records relating to those drone strikes. 
Thus, responding to plaintiffsโ FOIA request would, in fact, reveal information that
has not been officially disclosed, i.e., whether the CIA has responsive records
regarding the use of drone strikes.
The Court should reject plaintiffsโ attempt to cobble together an official CIA
acknowledgment by combining together the substance of various news reports,
unofficial statements, and imprecise statements by former CIA Director Panetta and
43

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 54 of 59
President Obama.  This Court has repeatedly recognized that there is a โstrict testโ for
official acknowledgment.  See, e.g, Moore, 666 F.3d at 1333.  That โinsistence on
exactitude recognizes โthe Governmentโs vital interest in information relating to
national security and foreign affairs.โโ Wolf, 473 F.3d at 378.  Plaintiffsโ very efforts
to try to piece together such an official acknowledgment from these disparate sources
demonstrate that there has not, in fact, been any prior, truly official acknowledgment
within the meaning of that longstanding precedent.  Indeed, it is just such an official
acknowledgment that plaintiffs seek to obtain, for the first time, from this suit.
44

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 55 of 59
CONCLUSION
For the foregoing reasons, the judgment of the district court should be affirmed.
Respectfully submitted,
STUART F. DELERY
  Acting Assistant Attorney General
RONALD C. MACHEN, JR.
  United States Attorney
BETH S. BRINKMANN
 Deputy Assistant Attorney General

s/ Catherine Y. Hancock           
CATHERINE Y. HANCOCK

  Washington, D.C.  20530-0001
45

USCA Case #11-5320      Document #1374831      Filed: 05/21/2012      Page 56 of 59

5 U.S.C. ยง 552:
(a) Each agency shall make available to the public information as follows:
* * *
(3)(A) Except with respect to the records made available under paragraphs (1) and
(2) of this subsection, and except as provided in subparagraph (E), each agency,
upon any request for records which (i) reasonably describes such records and (ii)
is made in accordance with published rules stating the time, place, fees (if any),
and procedures to be followed, shall make the records promptly available to any
person.
* * *
(b) This section does not apply to matters that are--
(1) (A) specifically authorized under criteria established by an Executive order to
be kept secret in the interest of national defense or foreign policy and (B) are in
fact properly classified pursuant to such Executive order; 
* * *
(3) specifically exempted from disclosure by statute (other than section 552b of
this title), if that statute-- 
(A)(i) requires that the matters be withheld from the public in such a manner as to
leave no discretion on the issue; or 
(ii) establishes particular criteria for withholding or refers to particular types of
matters to be withheld; and 
(B) if enacted after the date of enactment of the OPEN FOIA Act of 2009,
specifically cites to this paragraph.

documents.text:
Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 1 of 11
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT 
DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA 
   
AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION   
  125 Broad Street   
  New York, NY 10004,   
   
AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES UNION   
FOUNDATION   
  125 Broad Street   
  New York, NY 10004,   
   
Plaintiffs,  No. 10-cv-0436 (RMC) 
v. 
 
DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE 
  950 Pennsylvania Avenue, N.W. 
  Washington, DC 20530-0001, 
 
DEPARTMENT OF DEFENSE 
  1400 Defense Pentagon 
  Washington, DC 20301-1400, 
 
DEPARTMENT OF STATE 
  2201 C Street, N.W. 
  Washington, DC 20520, 
 
CENTRAL INTELLIGENCE AGENCY 
   Washington, D.C. 20505, 
         
Defendants. 
 
 
 
AMENDED COMPLAINT FOR INJUNCTIVE RELIEF 
 
 
1.  This is an action under the Freedom of Information Act (โFOIAโ), 5 
U.S.C. ยง 552, for injunctive and other appropriate relief, seeking the immediate 
processing and release of agency records requested by Plaintiffs American Civil Liberties 
Union and American Civil Liberties Union Foundation (collectively โACLUโ) from 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 2 of 11
Defendants U.S. Department of Justice (โDOJโ), U.S. Department of Defense (โDODโ), 
U.S. Department of State (โDOSโ), and the Central Intelligence Agency (โCIAโ). 
2.  Plaintiffs submitted a FOIA request (โthe Requestโ) to the DOD, CIA, 
DOS, DOJ, and one specific component of the DOJโthe Office of Legal Counsel 
(โOLCโ)โrequesting the release of records relating to the use of unmanned aerial 
vehiclesโcommonly known as โdronesโโfor the purpose of targeting and killing 
individuals since September 11, 2001. The Request was submitted to all agencies on 
January 13, 2010. 
3.  Although more than four months have elapsed since the Request was filed, 
none of the defendant agencies has released any record in response to the Request.  Nor 
has any defendant provided Plaintiffs with a processing schedule.  The defendants have 
provided inconsistent responses to Plaintiffsโ application for expedited processing, for a 
fee limitation on the basis of Plaintiffsโ status as representatives of the news media, and 
for a fee waiver on the basis that disclosure is in the public interest. 
4.  Plaintiffs now ask this Court to order the Defendants immediately to 
process all records responsive to the Request and to enjoin the Defendants from charging 
the Plaintiffs fees for processing the Request. 
Jurisdiction and Venue 
5.  This Court has both subject matter jurisdiction of the FOIA claim and 
personal jurisdiction over the parties pursuant to 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(B), (a)(6)(E)(iii). 
This Court also has jurisdiction over this action pursuant to 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331 and 5 
U.S.C. ยงยง 701-706. 
6.  Venue lies in this district under 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(B). 
  2 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 3 of 11
 
Parties 
7.   Plaintiff American Civil Liberties Union is a nationwide, non-profit, 
nonpartisan organization with more than 500,000 members dedicated to the constitutional 
principles of liberty and equality. The ACLU is committed to ensuring that the American 
government acts in compliance with the Constitution and laws, including its international 
legal obligations.  The ACLU is also committed to principles of transparency and 
accountability in government, and seeks to ensure that the American public is informed 
about the conduct of its government in matters that affect civil liberties and human rights.  
8.  Plaintiff American Civil Liberties Union Foundation is a separate 
ยง 501(c)(3) organization that educates the public about civil liberties and employs 
lawyers who provide legal representation free of charge in cases involving civil liberties. 
9.  Defendant DOD is a Department of the Executive Branch of the United 
States government and is an agency within the meaning of 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(f)(1). 
10.  Defendant DOJ is a Department of the Executive Branch of the United 
States government and is an agency within the meaning of 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(f)(1). The 
OLC is a component of the DOJ. 
11.  Defendant DOS is a Department of the Executive Branch of the United 
States government and is an agency within the meaning of 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(f)(1). 
12.  Defendant CIA is a Department of the Executive Branch of the United 
States government and is an agency within the meaning of 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(f)(1). 
 
 
  3 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 4 of 11
Factual Background.   
13.  Since at least 2002, the United States government has used unmanned 
aerial vehicles to conduct โtargeted killingsโ overseas.  Many of the drone strikes have 
taken place on bona fide battlefieldsโfor example, in Afghanistan.  In 2002, however, 
the U.S. conducted a drone strike in Yemen that killed several individuals including a 
U.S. citizen.  According to news reports, the frequency of drone strikes has increased 
significantly over the last few years, and in particular in the last year.  Unofficial 
estimates of the number and rate of civilian casualties in drone strikes vary significantly, 
from a rate of less than 10% to a rate of more than 90%. 
  FOIA Request 
14.  On January 13, 2010, the ACLU submitted a FOIA Request for records 
relating to the use of unmanned aerial vehicles by the CIA and the Armed Forces for the 
purpose of killing targeted individuals.  The Request was submitted to the designated 
FOIA offices of the DOD, CIA, DOS, DOJ, and OLC.  
15.  The Request seeks a variety of records relating to the use of unmanned 
aerial vehicles to conduct targeted killings, including the legal basis for the strikes and 
any legal limits on who may be targeted; where targeted drone strikes can occur; civilian 
casualties; which agencies or other non-governmental entities may be involved in 
conducting targeted killings; how the results of individual drone strikes are assessed after 
the fact; who may operate and direct targeted killing strikes; and how those involved in 
operating the program are supervised, overseen or disciplined. 
16.  Plaintiffs sought expedited processing of the Request on the grounds that 
there is a โcompelling needโ for these records because the information requested is 
  4 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 5 of 11
urgently needed by an organization primarily engaged in disseminating information in 
order to inform the public about actual or alleged Federal Government activity. See 5 
U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(6)(E)(v)(II); see also 22 C.F.R. ยง 171.12(b)(2); 28 C.F.R. ยง 
16.5(d)(1)(ii); 32 C.F.R. ยง 286.4(d)(3)(ii); 32 C.F.R. ยง 1900.34(c)(2). Plaintiffs also 
sought expedited processing on the grounds that the records sought relate to a โbreaking 
news story of general public interest.โ 22 C.F.R. ยง 171.12(b)(2)(i); 32 C.F.R. ยง 
286.4(d)(3)(ii)(A); see also 28 C.F.R. ยง 16.5(d)(1)(iv) (providing for expedited 
processing in relation to a โmatter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which 
there exist possible questions about the governmentโs integrity which affect public 
confidenceโ); 32 C.F.R. ยง 1900.34(c)(2) (providing for expedited processing when โthe 
information is relevant to a subject of public urgency concerning an actual or alleged 
Federal government activityโ). 
17.  Plaintiffs sought a waiver of search, review, and duplication fees on the 
grounds that disclosure of the requested records is โin the public interest because it is 
likely to contribute significantly to public understanding of the operations or activities of 
the government and is not primarily in the commercial interest of the requester.โ  See 5 
U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(A)(iii); see also 22 C.F.R. ยง 171.17(a); 28 C.F.R. ยง 16.11(k); 32 
C.F.R. ยง 286.28(d); 32 C.F.R. ยง 1900.13(b)(2). 
18.  Plaintiffs also sought a waiver of search and review fees on the grounds 
that the ACLU qualifies as a โrepresentative of the news mediaโ and that the records are 
not sought for commercial use. See 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(A)(ii); see also 22 C.F.R. ยงยง 
171.11(o), 171.15(c); 28 C.F.R. ยง 16.11(b)(6), (c), (d)(1); 32 C.F.R. ยง 286.28(e)(7); 32 
C.F.R. ยงยง 1900.02(h)(3), 1900.13(i)(2). 
  5 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 6 of 11
The Governmentโs Response to the Request 
19.  Although the Request has been pending for more than four months, no 
records have been produced.  The DOD, DOJ, and DOJ have not provided any basis for 
withholding responsive records.  The CIA has responded only by refusing to confirm or 
deny whether any responsive records exist. 
20.  By letter dated January 29, 2010 the DOD acknowledged receipt of the 
Request, but denied Plaintiffsโ application for expedited processing and also denied 
Plaintiffsโ application for waiver of search and review fees on the basis of โnews mediaโ 
requester status. 
21.  In the same letter the DOD deferred its decision on Plaintiffsโ application 
for a โpublic interestโ fee waiver, stating that it would decide the issue only after โa 
search for responsive records has been conducted and the volume and nature of 
responsive records have been determinedโ and that it would base its decision on the 
results of that search, rather than on the face of the Request.  DOD indicated that it would 
only conduct a two-hour search for records for this purpose, unless Plaintiff agreed in 
advance to pay for additional search time. 
22.  On March 11, 2010, Plaintiffs notified the DOD that it objected to the 
proposed manner of determining Plaintiffsโ entitlement to a public interest fee waiver.  
Plaintiffs nevertheless indicated that in the event the DOD refused to determine the fee 
waiver on the face of the Request, Plaintiffs were willing to commit $200 to cover search 
fees, in order to permit the DOD to base its public interest fee waiver decision on the 
basis of more than two hours of searching.  Plaintiffs reserved the right, however, to 
  6 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 7 of 11
appeal or apply for judicial review of both the process employed for determining the fee 
waiver, and any adverse determination on the issue. 
23.  On March 12, 2010, Plaintiff timely filed an administrative appeal of 
DODโs denial of news media requester status and of DODโs proposed procedure for 
determining the public interest fee waiver question.  Plaintiff urged the appellate 
authority to grant news media requester status and also to grant the public interest fee 
waiver based on an examination of the contents of the Request.  By letter dated March 
26, 2010 โ after the present lawsuit was filed naming DOD as a defendant โ DOD denied 
Plaintiffโs appeal in full, confirming the initial decisions to reject Plaintiffโs request for 
news media requester status and to defer Plaintiffโs fee waiver request until the search for 
documents is completed. 
24.  No further response or correspondence has been received from the DOD.  
No records responsive to the Request have been released by the DOD, nor has the DOD 
indicated that it has begun searching for or processing responsive records. 
25.  By letter dated January 29, 2010, the CIA acknowledged receipt of the 
Request but denied Plaintiffsโ request for expedited processing.  The CIA did not address 
Plaintiffsโ request for a public interest fee waiver or limitation of fees based on news 
media requester status.   
26.  By letter dated March 9, 2010, the CIA stated that the Request โis denied 
pursuant to FOIA exemptions (b)(1) and (b)(3) on the grounds that the โfact of the 
existence or nonexistence of requested records is currently and properly classified and is 
intelligences sources and methods that is protected from disclosure by section 6 of the 
  7 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 8 of 11
CIA Act of 1949, as amended.โ   The letter stated that this was the CIAโs โfinal responseโ 
to the Request, subject to appeal to the Agency Release Panel. 
27.  On April 22, 2010, Plaintiff timely filed an administrative appeal of CIAโs 
refusal to confirm or deny the existence of any records responsive to the Request.  
Plaintiff urged the appellate authority to reconsider its blanket refusal to process the 
request. 
28.  By letter dated May 6, 2010, the CIA acknowledged receipt of the appeal 
on April 23, 2010, but indicated that โit [is] unlikely that we can respond within 20 
working days,โ as required by 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(6)(A)(ii).  More than twenty days have 
elapsed since the appeal was received by the CIA and the CIA has not yet determined the 
appeal. 
29.  By letter dated February 3, 2010, the DOJ acknowledged receipt of the 
Request and informed the Plaintiff that the Request had been forwarded by the โreceipt 
and referral unitโ of the DOJ to the FBI, because it had determined that the FBI was the 
โcomponent[] most likely to have the recordsโ requested.  The Request was forwarded to 
the FBI on February 3, 2010.   By letter dated February 26, 2010, the FBI indicated that it 
had conducted a search of its Central Records System and was unable to find any 
responsive documents.  The FBIโs letter indicated that it regarded the request for fee 
waivers and expedited processing moot.  The FBI is not a defendant in this action. 
30.  By letter dated February 4, 2010, the OLC acknowledged receipt of the 
Request and granted Plaintiffsโ application for expedited processing, on the grounds that 
the Request involved โ[a] matter of widespread and exceptional media interest in which 
there exist possible questions about the governmentโs integrity which affect public 
  8 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 9 of 11
confidence.โ  28 C.F.R. ยง 16.5(d)(1)(iv).  The OLC did not make a decision on Plaintiffโs 
application for a public interest fee waiver or limitation of fees based on news media 
requester status, indicating that a decision on these issues would be made โafter [OLC] 
determine[s] whether or not fees will be assessed for this request.โ  No further response 
or correspondence has been received from the OLC.   
31.  By letter dated April 22, 2010 โ after the present lawsuit was filed naming 
DOS as a defendant โ DOS acknowledged receipt of the Request, granted Plaintiffโs 
application for expedited processing, and indicated that it would begin processing the 
Request.  The letter also stated that it would โdefer our decision to grant or deny 
[Plaintiffโs] request for a fee waiver until we are able to determine whether the disclosure 
of any documents responsive to your request is in the public interest.โ  DOS has not 
offered any response to Plaintiffโs request for news media requester status.  No further 
response or correspondence has been received from DOS. 
32.  Although more than four months have elapsed since the Request was 
submitted, no records responsive to the Request have been released by any of the 
Defendants.  None of the defendants in this action, with the exception of DOS, have 
indicated that they have even begun searching for or processing responsive records.   
33.  Events since the filing of the Request have only served to highlight the 
importance and urgency of the Request.  On February 3, 2010, Director of National 
Intelligence Dennis Blair confirmed, in public remarks at an open session of the 
Intelligence Committee of the House of Representatives, that the Unites States operates a 
program to target and kill individuals abroad.  He further confirmed that this program can 
involve โdirect action [that] involve[s] killing an American.โ  Investigative news reports 
  9 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 10 of 11
suggest that at least three U.S. citizens are on a list of individuals who can be targeted 
and killed, using drones or other means. 
Causes of Action 
34.  Defendantsโ failure to make a reasonable effort to search for records 
sought by the Request violates the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(3), and Defendantsโ 
corresponding regulations. 
35.  Defendantsโ failure to promptly make available the records sought by the 
Request violates the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(3)(A), and Defendantsโ corresponding 
regulations. 
36.  The failure of Defendants DOD and CIA to grant Plaintiffsโ request for 
expedited processing violates the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(6)(E), and Defendantsโ 
corresponding regulations. 
37.  Defendantsโ failure to grant Plaintiffsโ request for a limitation of fees 
violates FOIA, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(A)(ii)(II), and Defendantsโ corresponding 
regulations. 
38.  Defendantsโ failure to grant Plaintiffsโ request for a waiver of search, 
review, and duplication fees violates the FOIA, 5 U.S.C. ยง 552(a)(4)(A)(iii), and 
Defendantsโ corresponding regulations. 
 
 
 
 
 
  10 

Case 1:10-cv-00436-RMC   Document 11   Filed 06/01/10   Page 11 of 11
Requested Relief 
WHEREFORE, Plaintiffs respectfully request that this Court: 
A. Order Defendants immediately to process all records responsive to the 
Request; 
B. Enjoin Defendants from charging Plaintiffs search, review, or duplication fees 
for the processing of the Request; 
C. Award Plaintiffs their costs and reasonable attorneysโ fees incurred in this 
action; and 
D. Grant such other relief as the Court may deem just and proper.       
            Respectfully submitted,     
 
Arthur B. Spitzer       
     
             
Arthur B. Spitzer (D.C. Bar No. 235960) 
American Civil Liberties Union of the 
  Nationโs Capital 
            1400 20th Street, N.W., Suite 119 
            Washington, D.C.  20036 
            Phone: (202) 457-0800 
            Fax: (202) 452-1868 
            artspitzer@aol.com 
 
            Jonathan Manes       
            Jameel Jaffer  
            Ben Wizner 
American Civil Liberties Union Foundation 
125 Broad Street, 18th Floor 
New York, NY 10004 
Phone: (212) 549-2500 
Fax: (212) 549-2654 
jmanes@aclu.org  
jjaffer@aclu.org 
bwizner@aclu.org 
             
            Counsel for Plaintiffs

documents.title: Memorandum Opinion
documents.text:
UNITED STATES DISTRICT COURT
FOR THE DISTRICT OF COLUMBIA
)
AMERICAN CIVIL LIBERTIES, )
UNION, et al., )
)
Plaintiffs, )
)
v. ) Civil Action No. 10-0436 (RMC)
)
DEPARTMENT OF JUSTICE, et al., )
)
Defendants. )
)
MEMORANDUM OPINION
Alarmed at the reported use of unmanned drones to kill selected human targets in
Pakistan, Afghanistan, and elsewhere, the American Civil Liberties Union and the American Civil
Liberties Union Foundation submitted identical broad requests under the Freedom of Information
Act (โFOIAโ), 5 U.S.C. ยง 552, to the Central Intelligence Agency, the Department of Defense, the
Department of State, the Department of Justice, and DOJโs Office of Legal Counsel for records
documenting the alleged practice.  When the CIA refused to admit or deny that it had any relevant
records, and therefore denied the FOIA request, Plaintiffs sued and cited public comments by Leon
E. Panetta, former CIA Director, to support their argument that CIA use of drones has been officially
acknowledged and that a program of drone strikes is not an intelligence activity, source or method
protectable from disclosure under FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3.  Plaintiffs read the FOIA exemption
for intelligence gathering too narrowly and Mr. Panettaโs comments too broadly.  Whether or not the
CIA has any relevant records, that fact is exempt from disclosure under FOIA.  Summary judgment
will be granted to the CIA.

I.  FACTS
Plaintiffs ACLU and ACLU Foundation followed the customary path before bringing
this dispute to court.  The background facts are uncontested and are taken from the declaration of
Mary Ellen Cole, Information Review Officer for the CIA.  See CIAโs Mot. for Summ. J. [Dkt. # 15]
(โCIA Mem.โ), Ex. 1 (Declaration of Mary Ellen Cole (โCole Decl.โ)).  In a letter to the CIAโs
Information and Privacy Coordinator on January 13, 2010 (incorrectly dated as January 13, 2009),
Plaintiffs submitted a FOIA request seeking โrecords pertaining to the use of unmanned aerial
vehicles (โUAVsโ)โcommonly referred to as โdronesโ and including the MQ-1 Predator and MQ-9
Reaperโby the CIA and the Armed Forces for the purpose of killing targeted individuals.โ  Cole
Decl., Ex. A (Jan. 13, 2010 FOIA Request) (โFOIA Requestโ) at 2.  In particular, Plaintiffs were
seeking โinformation about the legal basis in domestic, foreign, and international law for the use of
drones to conduct targeted killings.โ  Id.
By letter dated March 9, 2010, the CIA issued a final response to Plaintiffsโ request,
stating that โthe CIA can neither confirm nor deny the existence or nonexistence of records
responsive to your request.โ  Id., Ex. B (Mar. 9, 2010 CIA Response).  The CIA explained that the
โfact of the existence or nonexistence of requested records is currently and properly classified and
is intelligence sources and methods information that is protected from disclosure by section 6 of the
CIA Act of 1949, as amended.โ  Id.  The CIA cited FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3 as the basis for its
response.  Id.  Plaintiffs appealed this denial on April 22, 2010.  Before the appeal was decided,
Plaintiffs filed an amended complaint on June 1, 2010, adding the CIA as defendant.1  The CIA
1  Plaintiffsโ January 13, 2010 FOIA request was simultaneously submitted to the U.S.
Department of Defense, Department of Justice, DOJโs Office of Legal Counsel, Department of State,
and CIA.  Plaintiffsโ original complaint brought suit against the Departments of Defense, Justice, and
-2-

thereafter closed the administrative appeal file.
Plaintiffs seek information on โdrone strikes;โ a term used by Plaintiffs (and the Court
for the sake of consistency) to mean the โtargeted killingโ of a human with a drone.  Paraphrasing
the ten categories of information listed in the FOIA request, Plaintiffs seek records pertaining to:
1. The โlegal basis in domestic, foreign and international law upon which unmanned
aerial vehiclesโ can be used to execute targeted killings, including who may be
targeted with this weapon system, where and why;
2. . . . . 
3. The โselection of human targets for drone strikes and any limits on who may be
targeted by a drone strike;โ
4. โ[C]ivilian  casualties  in  drone  strikes,โ  including  measures  to  limit  civilian
casualties;
5. The โassessment or evaluation of individual drone strikes after the fact,โ including
how the number and identities of victims are determined;
6. โ[G]eographical or territorial limits on the use of UAVs to kill targeted individuals;โ
7. The โnumber of drone strikes that have been executed for the purpose of killing
human targets, the location of each such strike, and the agency of the government or
branch of the military that undertook each such strike;โ
8. The โnumber, identity, status, and affiliation of individuals killed in drone strikes;โ
9. โ[W]ho may pilot UAVs, who may cause weapons to be fired from UAVs, or who
may otherwise be involved in the operation of UAVs for the purpose of executing
targeted killings,โ including records pertaining to the involvement of CIA personnel,
government contractors, or other non-military personnel, and;
10. The โtraining, supervision, oversight, or discipline of UAV operators and others
involved in the decision to execute a targeted killing using a drone.โ
Cole Decl., Ex. A (Jan. 13, 2010 FOIA Request) at 5โ8 (emphasis omitted).  In briefing, Plaintiffs
State; the amended complaint added the CIA as co-defendant.  See Am. Compl. [Dkt. # 11].  In this
Opinion, the Court addresses only Plaintiffsโ FOIA request for CIA records.  
-3-

abandoned their request of the CIA for information on category 2 and subcategory 1(B) as listed in
the FOIA request, both of which concern records on the understanding, cooperation or involvement
of foreign governments in drone strikes.  See Pls.โ Oppโn & Cross-Mot. for Summ. J. [Dkts. ## 20,
21] (โPls.โ Oppโnโ) at 3.
II.  LEGAL STANDARD
Under Rule 56 of the Federal Rules of Civil Procedure, summary judgment shall be
granted โif the movant shows that there is no genuine dispute as to any material fact and the movant
is entitled to judgement as a matter of law.โ  FED. R. CIV. P. 56(a); Anderson v. Liberty Lobby, Inc.,
477 U.S. 242, 247 (1986).  Moreover, summary judgment is properly granted against a party who
โafter adequate time for discovery and upon motion . . . fails to make a showing sufficient to
establish the existence of an element essential to that partyโs case, and on which that party will bear
the burden of proof at trial.โ  Celotex Corp. v. Catrett, 477 U.S. 317, 322 (1986).  In ruling on a
motion for summary judgment, the court must draw all justifiable inferences in the nonmoving
partyโs favor and accept the nonmoving partyโs evidence as true.  Anderson, 477 U.S. at 255.  A
nonmoving party; however, must establish more than โthe mere existence of a scintilla of evidenceโ
in support of its position.  Id. at 252.  
Federal district courts have original jurisdiction over civil actions arising under
federal statutes.  See 28 U.S.C. ยง 1331.  As Plaintiffs bring suit under FOIA, this Court has original
jurisdiction.  FOIA cases are typically and appropriately decided on motions for summary judgment. 
See, e.g., Rushford v. Civiletti, 485 F. Supp. 477, 481 n.13 (D.D.C. 1980); Reliant Energy Power
Generation, Inc. v. FERC, 520 F. Supp. 2d 194, 200 (D.D.C. 2007).  
Jurisdiction in a FOIA case is dependent upon a showing that an agency has
-4-

(1) improperly (2) withheld (3) agency records.  U.S. Depโt of Justice v. Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. 136,
142 (1989); United We Stand America, Inc. v. IRS, 359 F.3d 595, 598 (D.C. Cir. 2004).  The agency
bears the burden to demonstrate โ not the requester to disprove โ that it has not improperly withheld
agency records.  Tax Analysts, 492 U.S. at 142 n.3.  This is consistent with the purpose of FOIA
which was โenacted to facilitate public access to Government documents,โ U.S. Depโt of State v.
Ray, 502 U.S. 164, 173 (1991), in order โto pierce the veil of administrative secrecy and to open
agency action to the light of public scrutiny.โ  Depโt of Air Force v. Rose, 425 U.S. 352, 361 (1976). 
โConsistently with this purpose, as well as the plain language of the Act, the strong presumption in
favor of disclosure places the burden on the agency to justify the withholding of any requested
documents.โ  Ray, 502 U.S. at 173.
An agency may meet its burden solely on the basis of information provided in agency
declarations that describe โthe documents and the justifications for nondisclosure with reasonably
specific detail, demonstrate that the  information withheld logically falls within the claimed
exemption, and are not controverted by either contrary evidence in the record nor by evidence of
agency bad faith.โ  Military Audit Project v. Casey, 656 F.2d 724, 738 (D.C. Cir. 1981). 
โ[C]onclusory affidavits that merely recite statutory standards, or are overly vague or sweeping will
not, standing alone, carry the governmentโs burden.โ  Larson v. Depโt of State, 565 F.3d 857, 864
(D.C. Cir. 2009).  โUltimately, an agencyโs justification for invoking a FOIA exemption is sufficient
if it appears logical or plausible.โ  Id. at 862 (internal quotation marks omitted).  Further, the โcourt
owes substantial weight to detailed agency explanations in the national security context.โ  King v.
U.S. Depโt of Justice, 830 F.2d 210, 217 (D.C. Cir. 1987).  A โdefendant in a FOIA action is entitled
to summary judgment if the defendant proves that it has fully discharged its obligations under the
-5-

Act.โ  Reliant Energy, 520 F. Supp. 2d at 200. 
The exemptions under FOIA โcover not only the content of protected government
records but also the fact of their existence or nonexistence, if that fact itself properly falls within the
exemption.โ  Larson, 565 F.3d at 861.  Thus, an agency may refuse to confirm or deny the existence
of responsive records โ an answer commonly known as a Glomar response โ when โto answer the
FOIA inquiry would cause harm cognizable under an FOIA exception.โ  Gardels v. CIA, 689 F.2d
1100, 1103 (D.C. Cir. 1982); see also Larson, 565 F.3d at 861.  A Glomar response takes its name
from the Hughes Glomar Explorer, an oceanic research vessel at issue in the case that first authorized
the government to refuse to confirm or deny the existence of records responsive to a FOIA request. 
See generally Phillippi v. CIA, 546 F.2d 1009 (D.C. Cir. 1976). 
III.  ANALYSIS
Neither side disputes the customary principles that govern FOIA requests to the CIA. 
In this matter, the CIA has invoked FOIA Exemptions 1 and 3 to justify its Glomar response.  The
CIA โinvoked the Glomar response in this case because confirming or denying the existence or
nonexistence of CIA records responsive to Plaintiffsโ FOIA request would reveal classified
information that is protected from disclosure by statute. . . .  [S]uch a response would implicate
information concerning clandestine intelligence activities, intelligence sources and methods, and
U.S. foreign relations and foreign activities.โ  Cole Decl. ยถ 12; see also ยถ 15 (โ[T]he CIA asserted
a Glomar response to Plaintiffsโ request because the existence or nonexistence of CIA records
responsive to this request is a currently and properly classified fact, the disclosure of which
reasonably could be expected to cause damage to the national security.  What is classified is not just
individual records themselves on a document-by-document basis, but also the mere fact of whether
-6-

or not the CIA possesses responsive records that pertain to drone strikes.โ).
A.  Exemption 3
FOIA Exemption 3 authorizes the withholding of agency records on subject-matters
specifically exempted from disclosure by a non-FOIA statute, provided that such statute โ(i) requires
that the matters be withheld from the public in such a manner as to leave no discretion on the issue;
or (ii) establishes particular criteria for withholding or refers to particular types of matters to be
withheld.โ  5 U.S.C. ยง 552(b)(3).  To properly invoke Exemption 3, the CIA โneed only show that
the statute claimed is one of exemption as contemplated by Exemption 3 and that the withheld
material falls within the statute.โ  Larson, 565 F.3d at 865.  
The CIA first points to the Central Intelligence Agency Act of 1949, as amended, 50
U.S.C. ยง 403-4 et seq. (โCIA Actโ), which exempts the CIA from โany . . . law which require[s] the
publication or disclosure of the organization, functions, names, official titles, salaries, or numbers
of personnel employed by the Agency.โ  50 U.S.C. ยง 403g.  Secondly, the CIA proffers the National
Security Act of 1947, as amended, 50 U.S.C. ยง 401 et seq. (the โNSAโ), which mandates that the
โDirector of National Intelligence shall protect intelligence sources and methods from unauthorized
disclosure.โ  50 U.S.C. ยง 403-1(i)(1).  It is well-established that both statutory provisions cited by
the CIA qualify as withholding statutes for purposes of Exemption 3.  See, e.g., ACLU v. U.S. Depโt
of Defense, 628 F.3d 612, 619 (D.C. Cir. 2011); Halperin v. CIA, 629 F.2d 144, 147 (D.C. Cir.
1980); Majed Subh v. CIA, 760 F. Supp. 2d 66, 70 (D.D.C. 2011).   
1.  Whether Drone Strikes Relate to โFunctionsโ of CIA Personnel Under the
CIA Act?
The CIA claims it properly relies upon ยง 403g of the CIA Act to protect information
-7-

relating to the โfunctionsโ of its personnel; that is, โinformation relating to its core functions โ which
plainly include clandestine intelligence activities, intelligence sources and methods and foreign
liaison relationships.โ  Cole Decl. ยถ 41.  Plaintiffs counter that the CIA presents an overbroad reading
of CIA โfunctionsโ under the statute.  To be sure, the D.C. Circuit has recognized that ยง 403g is not
without limits:  it does not sanction the CIA to โrefuse to provide any information at all about
anything it doesโ under the guise that such information pertains to personnel โfunctions.โ  Phillippi,
546 F.2d at 1015 n.14.  The provision is designed primarily to shield the CIA from having to divulge
โinformation about its internal structure.โ  Id.  Accordingly, ยง 403g of the CIA Act offers a limited
sanctuary from the CIAโs FOIA obligations because โ[o]nly the specific information on the CIAโs
personnel and internal structure that is listed in the statute will obtain protection from disclosure.โ 
Baker v. CIA, 580 F.2d 664, 670 (D.C. Cir. 1978).  
The CIAโs Information Review Officer responds that the CIA is โcharged with
carrying out a number of important functions on behalf of the United States, which include, among
other activities, collecting and analyzing foreign intelligence and counterintelligence.โ  Cole Decl.
ยถ 13.  โA defining characteristic of the CIAโs intelligence activities is that they are typically carried
out through clandestine means, and therefore they must remain secret in order to be effective.โ  Id. 
โIn the context of FOIA, this means that the CIA must carefully evaluate whether its response to a
particular FOIA request could jeopardize the clandestine nature of its intelligence activities or
otherwise reveal previously undisclosed information about its sources, capabilities, authorities,
interests, strengths, weaknesses, resources, etc.โ  Id.

The CIA declaration offers โreasonable specificity of detail rather than merely

involvement in/operation of the drone program.  Although the matter is not entirely free from doubt,

the Court is satisfied that the CIA has properly invoked ยง 403g of the CIA Act to withhold this fact
